description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3.1) Gecko/20030425 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Win98; en-US; rv:1.3.1) Gecko/20030425  The main table should have a fixed position. To check this look at the borders of the top-left circle. If this perfectly aligns with the background the page rendered correctly. If there are small colored bits visible this is not the case. A reload solves this problem. On other pages (http://test.primerelay.net/domains/register/test.php/) A similar problem occurs. In the first step of this URL just enter a valid domain name and select the business-option at the bottom (others aren't implemented yet). When arriving at step 2 there are two options: the main table is at its correct position, or not. If this is not the case a reload and [ok] to the POST dialog gets it fixed. But when selecting any option from one of the pulldown menu's the whole table will jump down a bit.  Reproducible: Sometimes  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to http://test.primerelay.net/domains/register/test.php/ 2. Fill in a valid domain, choose .nl as tld and choose business. 3. If 'step 2' isn't rendered correctly solve this by reloading the page 4. Once it's displayed correctly select an option from one of the pulldown menu's 5. And watch the table shift downwards...  Actual Results:   A rendered table shifts its position on the screen  Expected Results:   The table should stay where it is. The table should also be at the good position, noticeable at the edges of the top-left circle.  Sometimes the main table gets displayed correctly. For now I haven't been able to find out why the pages are sometimes displayed correctly, and sometimes not. Above reported URL's are validated by the W3 Validator as valid HTML 4.01 Transitional.

description: User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.4b) Gecko/20030507 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.4b) Gecko/20030507 I have a page with a table row, and an in each cell (see near line 456 in the page's source). I use JavaScript and DHTML to alter the innerHTML of the table cells, so I can change the dimensions of these images (see JavaScript function "graphScore()", near line 115 in the page's source). Even though I use for the overall row, the image ends up switching back and forth from bottom vertical alignment to top vertical alignment. I also tried to explicitly set each but that doesn't help. Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. View page given in URL above. 2. Observe my green progress bar (labeled "History"). 3. To speed up page progress, go to my Options field and change the Retry interval to "Instant". 4. Let the progress go a few hundred iterations, so you can see the pattern. Actual Results: Table cell is rewritten, and image dimension changes correctly, but after a few dozen iterations, the vertical alignment switches to TOP. It might switch back to BOTTOM after another bunch of iterations. It switches back and forth inconsistently. Expected Results: The entire row of table cells should be vertically aligned BOTTOM. I notice that this page behaves correctly in MS Internet Explorer 6.x and in Opera 7.x.

description: In content/html/style/src/nsHTMLStyleSheet.cpp :  HTMLStyleSheetImpl::RulesMatching(...): 814       if (tag == nsHTMLAtoms::a) { 815         if (mLinkRule || mVisitedRule || mActiveRule) { 816           if (aData->mIsHTMLLink) { ... HTMLStyleSheetImpl::HasStateDependentStyle(...): 871   *aResult = mActiveRule && 872              (aData->mStateMask & NS_EVENT_STATE_ACTIVE) && 873              aData->mStyledContent && 874              aData->mIsHTMLContent && 875              aData->mContentTag == nsHTMLAtoms::a && 876              aData->mStyledContent->HasAttr(kNameSpaceID_None, 877                                             nsHTMLAtoms::href);  It seems that the two pieces of code should use the same algorithm to work out if the element is a link or not. In fact, it seems that they could both be simplified:         if (aData->mIsHTMLLink && (mLinkRule || mVisitedRule || mActiveRule)) {  ...and:     *aResult = mActiveRule &&               (aData->mStateMask & NS_EVENT_STATE_ACTIVE) &&               aData->mStyledContent &&               aData->mIsHTMLContent &&               aData->mIsHTMLLink;  That would have the side effect of also applying the attributes to <area> and <link> elements which might even be a good idea.  Anyway. Just something I spotted while browsing the code. It could be intentional of course.
my_mothod: In content/html/style/src/nsHTMLStyleSheet.cpp :  HTMLStyleSheetImpl::RulesMatching(...): 814       if (tag == nsHTMLAtoms::a) { 815         if (mLinkRule || mVisitedRule || mActiveRule) { 816           if (aData->mIsHTMLLink) { ... HTMLStyleSheetImpl::HasStateDependentStyle(...): 871   *aResult = mActiveRule && 872              (aData->mStateMask & NS_EVENT_STATE_ACTIVE) && 873              aData->mStyledContent && 874              aData->mIsHTMLContent && 875              aData->mContentTag == nsHTMLAtoms::a && 876              aData->mStyledContent->HasAttr(kNameSpaceID_None, 877                                             nsHTMLAtoms::href);  It seems that the two pieces of code should use the same algorithm to work out if the element is a link or not. In fact, it seems that they could both be simplified:         if (aData->mIsHTMLLink && (mLinkRule || mVisitedRule || mActiveRule)) {  ...and:     *aResult = mActiveRule &&               (aData->mStateMask & NS_EVENT_STATE_ACTIVE) &&               aData->mStyledContent &&               aData->mIsHTMLContent &&               aData->mIsHTMLLink;  That would have the side effect of also applying the attributes to <area> and <link> elements which might even be a good idea.  Anyway. Just something I spotted while browsing the code. It could be intentional of course. Inconsistency in link determination in HTMLStyleSheetImpl trivial CSS Parsing and Computation Core

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.5a) Gecko/20030715 Mozilla Firebird/0.6 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.5a) Gecko/20030715 Mozilla Firebird/0.6  Unknown document types in gopher: URLs cause a new, blank page to be displayed containing only the words    3Unknown Selector String .  which is strangely formatted. I would have expected no "3" and no space before the final full stop.  (For consistency, this should really be a matter for an error dialogue box, as seen when an unknown protocol is found in a URL.)  FYI, the document type "h" is in commonly use (it means text/html), but isn't one of the original set listed in RFC 1436. It would be good if Moz supported it, but that's not the point of this bug: the point is the strange error message.  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Go to gopher://sipb.mit.edu/ 2. Click the last entry, "New e-mail directory (http://usenet-addresses.mit.edu/)"  Or just go to gopher://sipb.mit.edu/hH:usenet-addresses.html

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.5b) Gecko/20030826 Mozilla Firebird/0.6.1+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.5b) Gecko/20030826 Mozilla Firebird/0.6.1+  This is a minor UI inconsistency brought about by how MailNews handled Plain Text vs. HTML domains.  In the Mozilla suite' MailNews, the Send Format option page has the Plain Text and HTML Domain lists on the same page, and each list has its own Add/Delete buttons. Under HTML Domains, the hotkey for Add is A and the one for Delete is L. Under Plain Text Domains Add's hotkey is D and Delete's is T. However, Thunderbird puts the two lists on different tabs, making the two sets of hotkeys unnecessary and confusing (D for Add). I'd suggest giving both pairs of buttons the same hotkeys (simply Alt-A for Add and Alt-D for Delete).  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Options/Composition/Send Options. 2. Note the different sets of hotkeys for the two pairs of buttons.  Actual Results:   Each pair has its own set of hotkeys.  Expected Results:   The same hotkeys should always refer to Add and Delete throughout Thunderbird's UI.
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.5b) Gecko/20030826 Mozilla Firebird/0.6.1+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.5b) Gecko/20030826 Mozilla Firebird/0.6.1+  This is a minor UI inconsistency brought about by how MailNews handled Plain Text vs. HTML domains.  In the Mozilla suite' MailNews, the Send Format option page has the Plain Text and HTML Domain lists on the same page, and each list has its own Add/Delete buttons. Under HTML Domains, the hotkey for Add is A and the one for Delete is L. Under Plain Text Domains Add's hotkey is D and Delete's is T. However, Thunderbird puts the two lists on different tabs, making the two sets of hotkeys unnecessary and confusing (D for Add). I'd suggest giving both pairs of buttons the same hotkeys (simply Alt-A for Add and Alt-D for Delete).  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open Options/Composition/Send Options. 2. Note the different sets of hotkeys for the two pairs of buttons.  Actual Results:   Each pair has its own set of hotkeys.  Expected Results:   The same hotkeys should always refer to Add and Delete throughout Thunderbird's UI. Inconsistent accesskeys for Add/Remove buttons on Send Options dialog trivial Preferences Thunderbird

description: In NSS 3.9 we added the following to the manifest.mn files in several NSS directories as part of the ECC checkin:  +ifdef NSS_ENABLE_ECC +DEFINES += -DNSS_ENABLE_ECC +endif  The manifest.mn files are the wrong place for this ifdef.  In the coreconf build system, manifest.mn files should only contain plain definitions of some make variables.  Any ifdef should be in some config.mk file.  The right solution is to add a new NSS config.mk file:      mozilla/security/nss/config/config.mk  move the above ifdef to that file, and have the relevant Makefile's include the NSS config.mk file in section 3 ("component" configuration information).  The new NSS config.mk will be useful for other similar ifdefs that apply to NSS but not to other coreconf-based projects.
my_mothod: In NSS 3.9 we added the following to the manifest.mn files in several NSS directories as part of the ECC checkin:  +ifdef NSS_ENABLE_ECC +DEFINES += -DNSS_ENABLE_ECC +endif  The manifest.mn files are the wrong place for this ifdef.  In the coreconf build system, manifest.mn files should only contain plain definitions of some make variables.  Any ifdef should be in some config.mk file.  The right solution is to add a new NSS config.mk file:      mozilla/security/nss/config/config.mk  move the above ifdef to that file, and have the relevant Makefile's include the NSS config.mk file in section 3 ("component" configuration information).  The new NSS config.mk will be useful for other similar ifdefs that apply to NSS but not to other coreconf-based projects. Remove unnecessary NSS_ENABLE_ECC defines from manifest.mn trivial Build NSS

description: When trying to install an extension targeted at another app (i.e. not Firefox) the error message says "XXX will only work with Firefox (null)". It would be better if it said something like "XXX is not compatible with Firefox". See the attachment for an example.
my_mothod: When trying to install an extension targeted at another app (i.e. not Firefox) the error message says "XXX will only work with Firefox (null)". It would be better if it said something like "XXX is not compatible with Firefox". See the attachment for an example. Incompatible extension warning needs different text for app incompatibility than version incompatibility trivial Add-ons Manager Toolkit

description: The throbber tooltip in Firefox is inaccurate with a custom browser.throbber.url.  The tooltip suggests clicking will go to the Firefox home page, which isn't true with another URL.  Bug 245271 comment 15 suggested browser.throbber.label for the pref name.  The relevant XUL attribute is "tooltiptext", and the entity is "&throbber.tooltip;".  I'd suggest one of those choices for consistency.  (There are no prefs containing the string "label" or "tooltip" in Firefox, so there's no pre-existing style in prefs nomenclature.)
my_mothod: The throbber tooltip in Firefox is inaccurate with a custom browser.throbber.url.  The tooltip suggests clicking will go to the Firefox home page, which isn't true with another URL.  Bug 245271 comment 15 suggested browser.throbber.label for the pref name.  The relevant XUL attribute is "tooltiptext", and the entity is "&throbber.tooltip;".  I'd suggest one of those choices for consistency.  (There are no prefs containing the string "label" or "tooltip" in Firefox, so there's no pre-existing style in prefs nomenclature.) Create preference for throbber tooltip trivial Toolbars and Customization Firefox

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7) Gecko/20040626 Firefox/0.9.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7) Gecko/20040626 Firefox/0.9.1  The Move button dialog box that appears has the words "Create in:" to the left of the folder tree. I think this should be "Move to:" as the bookmark is basically already created and the word Create might make people think that it makes a copy of the bookmark or something. Moving is what the user is expecting to take, not Creating.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. In Firefox, goto Bookmarks > Manage Bookmarks. 2. Click on a bookmark or folder to enabled the Move button. 3. Click Move on the toolbar.  Actual Results:   The dialog has the words "Create in".  Expected Results:   It would be a good idea for the words "Create in" to be changed to "Move to" for the reasons above.
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7) Gecko/20040626 Firefox/0.9.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7) Gecko/20040626 Firefox/0.9.1  The Move button dialog box that appears has the words "Create in:" to the left of the folder tree. I think this should be "Move to:" as the bookmark is basically already created and the word Create might make people think that it makes a copy of the bookmark or something. Moving is what the user is expecting to take, not Creating.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. In Firefox, goto Bookmarks > Manage Bookmarks. 2. Click on a bookmark or folder to enabled the Move button. 3. Click Move on the toolbar.  Actual Results:   The dialog has the words "Create in".  Expected Results:   It would be a good idea for the words "Create in" to be changed to "Move to" for the reasons above. Move dialog in Bookmarks Manager has words "Create in:" trivial Bookmarks & History Firefox

description: In the first screen of the Windows Firefox installer says, "...Click Next to continue the Setup program." at the end of the third paragraph. It then very nearly repeats this exact text in the next paragraph when it says "Click Next to continue installing Mozilla Firefox 0.9.0."    This redundancy seems a bit, well, redundant.
my_mothod: In the first screen of the Windows Firefox installer says, "...Click Next to continue the Setup program." at the end of the third paragraph. It then very nearly repeats this exact text in the next paragraph when it says "Click Next to continue installing Mozilla Firefox 0.9.0."    This redundancy seems a bit, well, redundant. redundancy in the wording in the first panel of installer trivial Installer Firefox

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; rv:1.7.3) Gecko/20040913 Firefox/0.10 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; rv:1.7.3) Gecko/20040913 Firefox/0.10  I have slashdot bookmarks as an rss feed. When I look at the headlines of the feed they all have the generic firefox placeholder bookmark. Only after I have visited a link of the feed is the icon changed to the site's icon. This bug is not limited only to slashdot's rss feed.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1.visit http://www.slashdot.org 2.add slashdot's rss feed as a bookmark 3.open slashdot's rss feed bookmarks and look at their icons, they will all have the generic icon. 4. visit a link from the feed, then check the rss bookmarks again,  the slashdot site icon will appear only next to the feed you just visited  Actual Results:    the site icon only appears for the rss link that was visited, not any of the others  Expected Results:   The site icon should appear for all of the rss links.
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; rv:1.7.3) Gecko/20040913 Firefox/0.10 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; rv:1.7.3) Gecko/20040913 Firefox/0.10  I have slashdot bookmarks as an rss feed. When I look at the headlines of the feed they all have the generic firefox placeholder bookmark. Only after I have visited a link of the feed is the icon changed to the site's icon. This bug is not limited only to slashdot's rss feed.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1.visit http://www.slashdot.org 2.add slashdot's rss feed as a bookmark 3.open slashdot's rss feed bookmarks and look at their icons, they will all have the generic icon. 4. visit a link from the feed, then check the rss bookmarks again,  the slashdot site icon will appear only next to the feed you just visited  Actual Results:    the site icon only appears for the rss link that was visited, not any of the others  Expected Results:   The site icon should appear for all of the rss links. live bookmarks pick up favicon only after visiting an item trivial Bookmarks & History Firefox

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a4) Gecko/20040920 Firefox/0.9.1+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a4) Gecko/20040920 Firefox/0.9.1+  When downloading a file of 19631008 bytes i.e. 18.72MB (from http://www.nero.com/en/download_previous.php?vpak=1) the download status shows X.X of 19.2 MB at YY.Y KB/sec.  After download the files size downloaded was checked and reported by windows as 19631008 bytes 18.7 MB. It seems like a factor of 1.024 is missing, i.e. KB has been divided by 1000 for MB instead of 1024. 19631008 bytes = 19171 KB (divided by 1024, as reported by Mozilla) 19171KB = 18.72MB (divided by 1024 as reported by Windows, and the Nero download site)  If you intend using MB as 1000KB and not 1024 KB then suggest leaving the size reported in KB as in Mozilla to avoid the problem.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Download file from URL above and compare reported size in MB with actual size in KB /1024 2. 3.  Actual Results:   Reported MB as KB/1000  Expected Results:   Reported MB as KB/1024  Compared with Mozilla nightly which shows download in KB and not in MB
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a4) Gecko/20040920 Firefox/0.9.1+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a4) Gecko/20040920 Firefox/0.9.1+  When downloading a file of 19631008 bytes i.e. 18.72MB (from http://www.nero.com/en/download_previous.php?vpak=1) the download status shows X.X of 19.2 MB at YY.Y KB/sec.  After download the files size downloaded was checked and reported by windows as 19631008 bytes 18.7 MB. It seems like a factor of 1.024 is missing, i.e. KB has been divided by 1000 for MB instead of 1024. 19631008 bytes = 19171 KB (divided by 1024, as reported by Mozilla) 19171KB = 18.72MB (divided by 1024 as reported by Windows, and the Nero download site)  If you intend using MB as 1000KB and not 1024 KB then suggest leaving the size reported in KB as in Mozilla to avoid the problem.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Download file from URL above and compare reported size in MB with actual size in KB /1024 2. 3.  Actual Results:   Reported MB as KB/1000  Expected Results:   Reported MB as KB/1024  Compared with Mozilla nightly which shows download in KB and not in MB Wrong download file size in MB is reported trivial Downloads API Toolkit

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a5) Gecko/20041018 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a5) Gecko/20041018  This is a "strict" error incoming only if "javascript.options.strict=true" (about:config)  If an html element has an event attribute like  onclick="javascript:return(returnValue('yes'));", then the javascript console shows a strict warning :  Warning:function onclick does not always return a value  whereas the function returnValue always returns a value.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set javascript.options.strict=true in about:config 2. Go to the test case 3. Open the javascript console 4. Clear the javascript console 3. Click on a radio button  Actual Results:   Javascript console: Warning:function onclick does not always return a value  Expected Results:   Javascript console: [nothing]  This bug is also on FireFox

Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set javascript.options.strict=true in about:config 2. Go to the test case 3. Open the javascript console 4. Clear the javascript console 3. Click on a radio button  Actual Results:   Javascript console: Warning:function onclick does not always return a value  Expected Results:   Javascript console: [nothing]  This bug is also on FireFox Javascript strict warnings : function _ does not always return a value trivial JavaScript Engine Core

description: "../../../../pr/src/misc/prenv.c", line 93: warning: argument #1 is incompatible with prototype:  This is because putenv() is declared to take char*, and we pass it const char*. Given the documented issues about persistence requirement for string, should we cast this to (char*) ? Or are there platforms where it's defined to take const char* ? Another way might be to fix the _MD_PUT_ENV macro to do the cast only on the OS where appropriate.

Given the documented issues about persistence requirement for string, should we cast this to (char*) ? Or are there platforms where it's defined to take const char* ? Another way might be to fix the _MD_PUT_ENV macro to do the cast only on the OS where appropriate. compiler warning in PR_SetEnv trivial NSPR NSPR

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.7.5) Gecko/20041107 Firefox/1.0 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.7.5) Gecko/20041107 Firefox/1.0  If a window from an extension (or from a browser window that cannot be opened from the sidebar without a specific extension) is opened in the sidebar, an error will show up in the JavaScript Console.  I have noticed this both in my current profile, and in a new one.  You may need to set "javascript.options.showInConsole" to "true" in about:config for this to show up.  The error is as follows:  Error: searchBox has no properties Source File: chrome://browser/content/browser.js Line: 3330  And the line is:  searchBox.focus();  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: 1. Install an extension which allows you to open up a window in the sidebar (Download Manager Tweak, EMButtons, QuickNote, etc.). 2. If not set up to do so by default, set up the extension to open up a window in the sidebar. 3. Open up the window affected by the extension, which should now open up in the sidebar. Actual Results:   The error mentioned above is generated in the JavaScript Console.  Expected Results:   The error mentioned above should not be generated at all.

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a6) Gecko/20041207 Firefox/1.0+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a6) Gecko/20041207 Firefox/1.0+  Sometime back, Mozilla did not allow you to select (and copy) the text contained in the Page Info dialog (and other dialogs).  However, now that the information is selectable, it can be useful for copying pertinent data from a page.  In the case of the title contained in the Page Info dialog, there is an added colon to the title.  It would be useful, for the purposes mentioned above to remove this colon, so a clean copy of the title can be obtained a little easier.  The only problem I see in this is that the colon is useful to represent information contained bellow similar to the following: 1) info 2) info So I'm not sure if it would be necessary to make a slight visual adjustment to make up for removing this.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce:
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a6) Gecko/20041207 Firefox/1.0+ Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8a6) Gecko/20041207 Firefox/1.0+  Sometime back, Mozilla did not allow you to select (and copy) the text contained in the Page Info dialog (and other dialogs).  However, now that the information is selectable, it can be useful for copying pertinent data from a page.  In the case of the title contained in the Page Info dialog, there is an added colon to the title.  It would be useful, for the purposes mentioned above to remove this colon, so a clean copy of the title can be obtained a little easier.  The only problem I see in this is that the colon is useful to represent information contained bellow similar to the following: 1) info 2) info So I'm not sure if it would be necessary to make a slight visual adjustment to make up for removing this.  Reproducible: Always Steps to Reproduce: Remove colon ":" from the title of the Page Info dialog (or make it unselectable) trivial Page Info Window Firefox

description: about: has no tables. The stylesheet contains   table {   margin: auto;   text-align: center; }  That should be removed.
my_mothod: about: has no tables. The stylesheet contains   table {   margin: auto;   text-align: center; }  That should be removed. Extraneous stylesheet rules for table in about: trivial General Firefox

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.6) Gecko/20050321 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.6) Gecko/20050321  The date ranges listed for the copyrights in the "about:" page use hyphens.  However, in English an en-dash is used to indicate ranges.  Thus the text  Copyright © 1998-2005  should in fact read  Copyright © 1998–2005  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Help->About Mozilla
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.6) Gecko/20050321 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.7.6) Gecko/20050321  The date ranges listed for the copyrights in the "about:" page use hyphens.  However, in English an en-dash is used to indicate ranges.  Thus the text  Copyright © 1998-2005  should in fact read  Copyright © 1998–2005  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Help->About Mozilla Incorrect typography in about: page (Help->About Mozilla) trivial Help Documentation SeaMonkey

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.2) Gecko/20040804 Netscape/7.2 (ax) Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.2) Gecko/20040804 Netscape/7.2 (ax)  The default template for bug/create/create-guided.html references the phrase "Zarro Boogs" directly in the HTML.  However, there seems to be a pre-defined variable (terms.zeroSearchResults in global/variables.none.tmpl) which defaults to "Zarro Boogs".  Should the code in create-guided.html.tmpl have "Zarro Boogs" hard-coded in HTML, or should it instead have "[% terms.zeroSearchResults %]"?  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce:
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.2) Gecko/20040804 Netscape/7.2 (ax) Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.7.2) Gecko/20040804 Netscape/7.2 (ax)  The default template for bug/create/create-guided.html references the phrase "Zarro Boogs" directly in the HTML.  However, there seems to be a pre-defined variable (terms.zeroSearchResults in global/variables.none.tmpl) which defaults to "Zarro Boogs".  Should the code in create-guided.html.tmpl have "Zarro Boogs" hard-coded in HTML, or should it instead have "[% terms.zeroSearchResults %]"?  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: create-guided template refers to "zarro boogs" instead of terms.zeroSearchResults trivial User Interface Bugzilla

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b5) Gecko/20051006 Firefox/1.4.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b5) Gecko/20051006 Firefox/1.4.1  Currently the URL can be auto-completed even if nothing is entered, hence resulting in URLs like http://www..com, http://www..net, and http://www..org  As empty URL is not visited (i.e. try pressing Enter in an empty location bar), empty URL should not be auto-completed as well.  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Empty the location bar (e.g. by opening a new blank window/tab) 2. Press Ctrl + Enter, Shift + Enter or Ctrl + Shift + Enter  Actual Results:   Firefox auto-completes the empty URL and visit the non-existent URLs http://www..com, http://www..net, and http://www..org respectively.  Expected Results:   Stay on the current page.
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b5) Gecko/20051006 Firefox/1.4.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.8b5) Gecko/20051006 Firefox/1.4.1  Currently the URL can be auto-completed even if nothing is entered, hence resulting in URLs like http://www..com, http://www..net, and http://www..org  As empty URL is not visited (i.e. try pressing Enter in an empty location bar), empty URL should not be auto-completed as well.  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Empty the location bar (e.g. by opening a new blank window/tab) 2. Press Ctrl + Enter, Shift + Enter or Ctrl + Shift + Enter  Actual Results:   Firefox auto-completes the empty URL and visit the non-existent URLs http://www..com, http://www..net, and http://www..org respectively.  Expected Results:   Stay on the current page. Empty URL should not be auto-completed trivial Address Bar Firefox

description: It seems to me that the comment in nsSelection.cpp in nsTypeSelection::AddRange(), namely:  5594 NS_IMETHODIMP 5595 nsTypedSelection::AddRange(nsIDOMRange* aRange) 5596 { 5597   if (!aRange) return NS_ERROR_NULL_POINTER; 5598  5599   // This inserts a table cell range in proper document order 5600   //  and returns NS_ERROR_FAILURE if range doesn't contain just one table             cell 5601   PRBool didAddRange; 5602   nsresult result = addTableCellRange(aRange, &didAddRange); 5603   if (NS_FAILED(result)) return result;  ...should say NS_OK, not NS_ERROR_FAILURE.
my_mothod: It seems to me that the comment in nsSelection.cpp in nsTypeSelection::AddRange(), namely:  5594 NS_IMETHODIMP 5595 nsTypedSelection::AddRange(nsIDOMRange* aRange) 5596 { 5597   if (!aRange) return NS_ERROR_NULL_POINTER; 5598  5599   // This inserts a table cell range in proper document order 5600   //  and returns NS_ERROR_FAILURE if range doesn't contain just one table             cell 5601   PRBool didAddRange; 5602   nsresult result = addTableCellRange(aRange, &didAddRange); 5603   if (NS_FAILED(result)) return result;  ...should say NS_OK, not NS_ERROR_FAILURE. Comment wrong in nsSelection.cpp trivial Layout Core

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; fr; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060124 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; fr; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060124 Firefox/1.5.0.1  http://lxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/source/netwerk/protocol/http/src/nsHttpNTLMAuth.cpp#218  :   63   64 static PRBool  65 MatchesBaseURI(const nsCSubstring &matchScheme,  66                const nsCSubstring &matchHost,  67                PRInt32             matchPort,  68                const char         *baseStart,  69                const char         *baseEnd)  70 {  71     // check if scheme://host:port matches baseURI  72   73     // parse the base URI  74     const char *hostStart, *schemeEnd = strstr(baseStart, "://");  75     if (schemeEnd) {  76         // the given scheme must match the parsed scheme exactly  77         if (!matchScheme.Equals(Substring(baseStart, schemeEnd)))  78             return PR_FALSE;  79         hostStart = schemeEnd + 3;  80     }  81     else  82         hostStart = baseStart;  83   84     // XXX this does not work for IPv6-literals  85     const char *hostEnd = strchr(hostStart, ':');  86     if (hostEnd && hostEnd <= baseEnd) {  87         // the given port must match the parsed port exactly  88         int port = atoi(hostEnd + 1);  89         if (matchPort != (PRInt32) port)  90             return PR_FALSE;  91     }  92     else  93         hostEnd = baseEnd;  94   Line 86, hostEnd is "<=" with baseEnd instead of "<". Because of this small error, it is possible to have hostEnd out-of-bound line 88... That could eventually lead to an information disclosure (not easy).   Reproducible: Didn't try
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; fr; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060124 Firefox/1.5.0.1 Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; fr; rv:1.8.0.1) Gecko/20060124 Firefox/1.5.0.1  http://lxr.mozilla.org/mozilla/source/netwerk/protocol/http/src/nsHttpNTLMAuth.cpp#218  :   63   64 static PRBool  65 MatchesBaseURI(const nsCSubstring &matchScheme,  66                const nsCSubstring &matchHost,  67                PRInt32             matchPort,  68                const char         *baseStart,  69                const char         *baseEnd)  70 {  71     // check if scheme://host:port matches baseURI  72   73     // parse the base URI  74     const char *hostStart, *schemeEnd = strstr(baseStart, "://");  75     if (schemeEnd) {  76         // the given scheme must match the parsed scheme exactly  77         if (!matchScheme.Equals(Substring(baseStart, schemeEnd)))  78             return PR_FALSE;  79         hostStart = schemeEnd + 3;  80     }  81     else  82         hostStart = baseStart;  83   84     // XXX this does not work for IPv6-literals  85     const char *hostEnd = strchr(hostStart, ':');  86     if (hostEnd && hostEnd <= baseEnd) {  87         // the given port must match the parsed port exactly  88         int port = atoi(hostEnd + 1);  89         if (matchPort != (PRInt32) port)  90             return PR_FALSE;  91     }  92     else  93         hostEnd = baseEnd;  94   Line 86, hostEnd is "<=" with baseEnd instead of "<". Because of this small error, it is possible to have hostEnd out-of-bound line 88... That could eventually lead to an information disclosure (not easy).   Reproducible: Didn't try Very little bug in MatchesBaseURI trivial Networking: HTTP Core

description: I don't think this is supposed to happen. I believe coverity has ways that you can hint to it about conditions you want, so we could either use that hint, or just set rv to NS_ERROR_NOT_AVAILABLE or something so that the code doesn't trigger the case (which seems cheaper to me than adding a coverity specific marker).
my_mothod: I don't think this is supposed to happen. I believe coverity has ways that you can hint to it about conditions you want, so we could either use that hint, or just set rv to NS_ERROR_NOT_AVAILABLE or something so that the code doesn't trigger the case (which seems cheaper to me than adding a coverity specific marker). [FIX]NS_ScriptErrorReporter would use rv uninitialized if !message && !report trivial DOM: Core & HTML Core

description: The checks for emailProfile!=NULL and profileTime!=NULL are redundant since they were checked to be not NULL a couple of lines earlier.  812  } else if (profileTime && emailProfile) {  @@ -815,18 +815,13 @@                 NSSItem profTime, profData;                 NSSItem *pprofTime, *pprofData;                 NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&subject, &cert->derSubject); -               if (profileTime) { -                   NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profTime, profileTime); -                   pprofTime = &profTime; -               } else { -                   pprofTime = NULL; -               } -               if (emailProfile) { -                   NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profData, emailProfile); -                   pprofData = &profData; -               } else { -                   pprofData = NULL; -               } + +               NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profTime, profileTime); +               pprofTime = &profTime; + +               NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profData, emailProfile); +               pprofData = &profData; +                 stanProfile = nssSMIMEProfile_Create(c, pprofTime, pprofData);                 if (!stanProfile) goto loser;                 nssrv = nssCryptoContext_ImportSMIMEProfile(cc, stanProfile);
my_mothod: The checks for emailProfile!=NULL and profileTime!=NULL are redundant since they were checked to be not NULL a couple of lines earlier.  812  } else if (profileTime && emailProfile) {  @@ -815,18 +815,13 @@                 NSSItem profTime, profData;                 NSSItem *pprofTime, *pprofData;                 NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&subject, &cert->derSubject); -               if (profileTime) { -                   NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profTime, profileTime); -                   pprofTime = &profTime; -               } else { -                   pprofTime = NULL; -               } -               if (emailProfile) { -                   NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profData, emailProfile); -                   pprofData = &profData; -               } else { -                   pprofData = NULL; -               } + +               NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profTime, profileTime); +               pprofTime = &profTime; + +               NSSITEM_FROM_SECITEM(&profData, emailProfile); +               pprofData = &profData; +                 stanProfile = nssSMIMEProfile_Create(c, pprofTime, pprofData);                 if (!stanProfile) goto loser;                 nssrv = nssCryptoContext_ImportSMIMEProfile(cc, stanProfile); Coverity 411, dead code in mozilla/security/nss/lib/certdb/stanpcertdb.c trivial Libraries NSS

description: pk11obj.c:1143:4: warning: "/*" within comment pk11obj.c:1152:17: warning: "/*" within comment pk11obj.c:1162:7: warning: "/*" within comment  could this please be addressed? i know it's sample code, but perhaps  #undef SAMPLE_CODE #ifdef SAMPLE_CODE ... #endif  would be better, then the code would be recognized by syntax highlighters, the /* embedded in the code */ would be treated as a comment and the compiler would not complain about it.
my_mothod: pk11obj.c:1143:4: warning: "/*" within comment pk11obj.c:1152:17: warning: "/*" within comment pk11obj.c:1162:7: warning: "/*" within comment  could this please be addressed? i know it's sample code, but perhaps  #undef SAMPLE_CODE #ifdef SAMPLE_CODE ... #endif  would be better, then the code would be recognized by syntax highlighters, the /* embedded in the code */ would be treated as a comment and the compiler would not complain about it. warning: "/*" within comment trivial Libraries NSS

description: Spin off of Bug 332759 Comment #49 Remaining questions (2).  Action of setTimeout("...",Infinity) is inconsistent between MS Win and Linux.   MS Win: Timeout will not fire (possibly long timeout value)   Linux : Timeout fires as if Infinity==0  (Mac OS: Sorry but I don't know) This may be a result of difference of spec of timer routines of OS.  I think non number millisecond value for setTimeout and setInterval is to be (A) rejected as "Invalid parameter" or (B) defaulted to several seconds or longer if non number is acepted.   This will reduce impact of(when B) or never cause(when A) problem of infinite loop by "function x(){setTimeout(x);}x();" or variations of it. And illegal number for millisecond value such as Infinity/-Infinity/Negative number is also to be rejected or defaulted to apprriate value instead of ZERO. Further, ZERO as millisecond value is to be rejected or defaulted to appropriate(safer) value.
my_mothod: Spin off of Bug 332759 Comment #49 Remaining questions (2).  Action of setTimeout("...",Infinity) is inconsistent between MS Win and Linux.   MS Win: Timeout will not fire (possibly long timeout value)   Linux : Timeout fires as if Infinity==0  (Mac OS: Sorry but I don't know) This may be a result of difference of spec of timer routines of OS.  I think non number millisecond value for setTimeout and setInterval is to be (A) rejected as "Invalid parameter" or (B) defaulted to several seconds or longer if non number is acepted.   This will reduce impact of(when B) or never cause(when A) problem of infinite loop by "function x(){setTimeout(x);}x();" or variations of it. And illegal number for millisecond value such as Infinity/-Infinity/Negative number is also to be rejected or defaulted to apprriate value instead of ZERO. Further, ZERO as millisecond value is to be rejected or defaulted to appropriate(safer) value. Action of setTimeout("...",Infinity) is inconsistent  between MS Win(timeout not fire) and Linux(timeout fires as if Infinity==0) trivial DOM: Core & HTML Core

description: So, i've been using bugzilla now for 3 weeks. hrm, there's something very wrong with that statement, but please bear with me :). Note that normally I file bugs against bugzilla 2.20.1, I'm going to have to be careful to try to remember to set the version number appropriately based on what I'm using.  Anyway, it turns out that whne I look at users, I see:  Thing Confusing <confusing.thing@do.main>  I've started typing "Thi" in the multiselect add cc listbox in order to enable me to CC someone named "Thing Confusing", this almost makes sense. Except for one minor detail.  Under additional comments there's this:  [ ] Add confusing.thing@do.main to CC list   I have no idea what confusing.thing is, even though it happens to be me, because I now think of myself as "Thing Confusing". While it might make perfect sense to offer "add email address to CC list", it's not what I come to expect when the CC list items list real name first and not email addresses.  Steps to reproduce: 1. setup user email accounts using longfirst.last@do.main 2. mess up your users tiny little minds by sticking last name first into the real name field 3. have them use bugzilla to CC a number of other people to bugs for 2 weeks. 4. let your user decide to visit amsterdam (this isn't strictly required to reproduce, but it's quite fun, I highly recommend it, but bring hard currency, they don't take American Express, or Visa, or MasterCard, although they sometimes take MaestroCard [go figure]) 5. send your user a bugmail showing a cc of your user, as a reminder to your user that your user should perhaps CC self to bugs while making changes/reassignments. 6. as user, try to cc yourself using the CC list, since after all, that's the logical thing to do. 7. as user, read the bug page and totally fail to comprehend what this Add confusing.thing@do.main to CC list is.  Expected results: Add option at the very least needs to have Real Name included in the same order as it would appear in CC List.  It should probably also include a hint (which could be disabled by the user upon recognizing what the BLEEP the feature is for, that explains that this is a way to _add yourself_ to the CC list).
my_mothod: So, i've been using bugzilla now for 3 weeks. hrm, there's something very wrong with that statement, but please bear with me :). Anyway, it turns out that whne I look at users, I see:  Thing Confusing <confusing.thing@do.main>  I've started typing "Thi" in the multiselect add cc listbox in order to enable me to CC someone named "Thing Confusing", this almost makes sense. Except for one minor detail.  Under additional comments there's this:  [ ] Add confusing.thing@do.main to CC list   I have no idea what confusing.thing is, even though it happens to be me, because I now think of myself as "Thing Confusing". While it might make perfect sense to offer "add email address to CC list", it's not what I come to expect when the CC list items list real name first and not email addresses.  Steps to reproduce: 1. setup user email accounts using longfirst.last@do.main 2. mess up your users tiny little minds by sticking last name first into the real name field 3. have them use bugzilla to CC a number of other people to bugs for 2 weeks. 4. let your user decide to visit amsterdam (this isn't strictly required to reproduce, but it's quite fun, I highly recommend it, but bring hard currency, they don't take American Express, or Visa, or MasterCard, although they sometimes take MaestroCard [go figure]) 5. send your user a bugmail showing a cc of your user, as a reminder to your user that your user should perhaps CC self to bugs while making changes/reassignments. 6. as user, try to cc yourself using the CC list, since after all, that's the logical thing to do. 7. as user, read the bug page and totally fail to comprehend what this Add confusing.thing@do.main to CC list is.  Expected results: Add option at the very least needs to have Real Name included in the same order as it would appear in CC List.  It should probably also include a hint (which could be disabled by the user upon recognizing what the BLEEP the feature is for, that explains that this is a way to _add yourself_ to the CC list). description: buildASN1ObjectFromDER is passed a parent pointer, not a pointer-to-a-pointer, so attempts to assign things to parent will simply leak. But in fact we don't get this far because NS_ENSURE_ARG_POINTER(parent) will return in the error case.  http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/security/manager/ssl/src/nsNSSASN1Object.cpp&rev=1.12&mark=126,134,151-156#124  (found while reviewing bug 283565)
my_mothod: buildASN1ObjectFromDER is passed a parent pointer, not a pointer-to-a-pointer, so attempts to assign things to parent will simply leak. But in fact we don't get this far because NS_ENSURE_ARG_POINTER(parent) will return in the error case.  http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/security/manager/ssl/src/nsNSSASN1Object.cpp&rev=1.12&mark=126,134,151-156#124  (found while reviewing bug 283565) unreachable code in buildASN1ObjectFromDER trivial Security: PSM Core

description: The functions functions SEC_OpenPermCertDB and SEC_FindPermCertByKey are declared in certdb.h, but they are not defined.  Their declarations should be removed.
my_mothod: The functions functions SEC_OpenPermCertDB and SEC_FindPermCertByKey are declared in certdb.h, but they are not defined.  Their declarations should be removed. Remove the declarations of nonexistent functions SEC_OpenPermCertDB and SEC_FindPermCertByKey. trivial Libraries NSS

description: Actual Results: > the [request] system is *extremely* flexible and can do what you need.  Expected Results: I'd request that the word "extremely" be replaced with very or fairly. Not to rain on anyone's parade, but I think that a little rain here is needed to clear up some clouds or something.

description: The Hungarian version of Firefox 3 or any other Mozilla 1.9 product fails to build on all three primary platforms, due to missing strings. It might be worth temporarily placing English strings in place of the missing ones until translation is complete so that at least partially translated nightlies are generated.  This is a blocker because it completely prevents building Firefox 3.0 betas or any other 1.9 products. This is a regression from 1.8.
my_mothod: The Hungarian version of Firefox 3 or any other Mozilla 1.9 product fails to build on all three primary platforms, due to missing strings. It might be worth temporarily placing English strings in place of the missing ones until translation is complete so that at least partially translated nightlies are generated.  This is a blocker because it completely prevents building Firefox 3.0 betas or any other 1.9 products. This is a regression from 1.8. Mozilla 1.9/Firefox 3 Hungarian doesn't build blocker hu / Hungarian Mozilla Localizations

description: Created attachment 303839 fix  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #416665 +++  Generator expresion decompiler changes included mis-braced code, resulting in failure to set saveop to JSOP_NAME, to avoid decompiling a generator expression as a generator function that's called immediately. The failure happens only if the generator expression runs up against the end of a comma, &&, or || term.  /be
my_mothod: Created attachment 303839 fix  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #416665 +++  Generator expresion decompiler changes included mis-braced code, resulting in failure to set saveop to JSOP_NAME, to avoid decompiling a generator expression as a generator function that's called immediately. The failure happens only if the generator expression runs up against the end of a comma, &&, or || term.  /be Misindented else-clause code in generator expression decompiler code trivial JavaScript Engine Core

description: Found by Coverity on its last Firefox 3 test run, 2007-May-14  CID 1150 In function ocsp_CreateCertID, variable tempItem is initialized to NULL  1593 	    SECItem *tempItem = NULL;  and then is not touched again until label loser, where it is checked for NULL.  1665 	    if (tempItem != NULL) { 1666 		SECITEM_FreeItem(tempItem, PR_TRUE); 1667 	    }  That condition can never be true.  It's dead code.  All the lines shown above should be removed.
my_mothod: Found by Coverity on its last Firefox 3 test run, 2007-May-14  CID 1150 In function ocsp_CreateCertID, variable tempItem is initialized to NULL  1593 	    SECItem *tempItem = NULL;  and then is not touched again until label loser, where it is checked for NULL.  1665 	    if (tempItem != NULL) { 1666 		SECITEM_FreeItem(tempItem, PR_TRUE); 1667 	    }  That condition can never be true.  It's dead code.  All the lines shown above should be removed. Coverity 1150 - dead code in ocsp_CreateCertID trivial Libraries NSS

description: Bug 221335 changed the type of |txMozillaTextOutput::mDocument| and |txTransformNotifier::mDocument| from nsIDOMDocument* to nsIDocument*.  > nsCOMPtr<nsIDocument> mDocument;  http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.h&rev=1.34&mark=86#86  However, mDocument still QI to nsIDocument*.  > nsCOMPtr<nsIDocument> doc = do_QueryInterface(mDocument);   http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.cpp&rev=1.86&mark=273#273 http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.cpp&rev=1.86&mark=804#804 http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.cpp&rev=1.86&mark=1111#1111  If I understand right, these are meaningless, while they are harmless as well.  BTW, is it possible to detect such a code systematically?  I mean, for example, editing QI's macro implementation to check if QI-destination is same as the original type...?
my_mothod: Bug 221335 changed the type of |txMozillaTextOutput::mDocument| and |txTransformNotifier::mDocument| from nsIDOMDocument* to nsIDocument*.  > nsCOMPtr<nsIDocument> mDocument;  http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.h&rev=1.34&mark=86#86  However, mDocument still QI to nsIDocument*.  > nsCOMPtr<nsIDocument> doc = do_QueryInterface(mDocument);   http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.cpp&rev=1.86&mark=273#273 http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.cpp&rev=1.86&mark=804#804 http://bonsai.mozilla.org/cvsblame.cgi?file=mozilla/content/xslt/src/xslt/txMozillaXMLOutput.cpp&rev=1.86&mark=1111#1111  If I understand right, these are meaningless, while they are harmless as well.  BTW, is it possible to detect such a code systematically?  I mean, for example, editing QI's macro implementation to check if QI-destination is same as the original type...? Remove some nsIDocument QIs from txMozillaTextOutput.cpp trivial XSLT Core

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.8.1.16) Gecko/20080715 Fedora/2.0.0.16-1.fc8 Firefox/2.0.0.16 Build Identifier: CVS head  When compiling a program that includes using NSS under gcc4 (gcc (GCC) 4.1.2 20070925 (Red Hat 4.1.2-33)) with:  gcc -Wstrict-prototypes -I /usr/include/nss3 -I /usr/include/nspr4 -o test test.c  I get the following warning:  /usr/include/nss3/pk11pub.h:249: warning: function declaration isn’t a prototype  The attached patch clears up the warning.  Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Compile the attached trivial program with gcc4 (I didn't check other versions of gcc to see if they behave differently):  gcc -Wstrict-prototypes -I /usr/include/nss3 -I /usr/include/nspr4 -o test test.c Actual Results:   [user@host NSS]$ gcc -Wstrict-prototypes -I /usr/include/nss3 -I /usr/include/nspr4 -o test test.c In file included from test.c:1: /usr/include/nss3/pk11pub.h:249: warning: function declaration isn’t a prototype [user@host NSS]$  Expected Results:   No warning

Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Compile the attached trivial program with gcc4 (I didn't check other versions of gcc to see if they behave differently):  gcc -Wstrict-prototypes -I /usr/include/nss3 -I /usr/include/nspr4 -o test test.c Actual Results:   [user@host NSS]$ gcc -Wstrict-prototypes -I /usr/include/nss3 -I /usr/include/nspr4 -o test test.c In file included from test.c:1: /usr/include/nss3/pk11pub.h:249: warning: function declaration isn’t a prototype [user@host NSS]$  Expected Results:   No warning PK11_CreateMergeLog() declaration causes gcc warning when compiling with -Wstrict-prototypes trivial Libraries NSS

description: The boolean charts contain the option "contains regexp" which isn't what it actually means. It should be changed to "matches regexp", which is what the search actually does.
my_mothod: The boolean charts contain the option "contains regexp" which isn't what it actually means. It should be changed to "matches regexp", which is what the search actually does. Boolean chart contains the phrase "contains regexp" when it should say "matches regexp" trivial Query/Bug List Bugzilla

description: http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/security/nss/lib/ckfw/hash.c#82 81 static PLHashNumber 82 nss_ckfw_identity_hash 83 ( 84   const void *key 85 ) 86 { 87   PRUint32 i = (PRUint32)key; 88   PR_ASSERT(sizeof(PLHashNumber) == sizeof(PRUint32)); 89   return (PLHashNumber)i; 90 }  the cast from (void *) to PRUint32 is wrong and is detected by gcc at compile time: hash.c: In function ‘nss_ckfw_identity_hash’: hash.c:87: warning: cast from pointer to integer of different size  i am not familiar with the programming logic to tell the implications of this.
my_mothod: http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/security/nss/lib/ckfw/hash.c#82 81 static PLHashNumber 82 nss_ckfw_identity_hash 83 ( 84   const void *key 85 ) 86 { 87   PRUint32 i = (PRUint32)key; 88   PR_ASSERT(sizeof(PLHashNumber) == sizeof(PRUint32)); 89   return (PLHashNumber)i; 90 }  the cast from (void *) to PRUint32 is wrong and is detected by gcc at compile time: hash.c: In function ‘nss_ckfw_identity_hash’: hash.c:87: warning: cast from pointer to integer of different size  i am not familiar with the programming logic to tell the implications of this. 64 bit warning in nss_ckfw_identity_hash trivial Libraries NSS

description: This was noticed in bug 464695 comment 1.  The links on the gonefishing error page point to ftp://ftp.mozilla.org, which intentionally blocks access to the latest releases to avoid people linking there directly. They should link to releases.mozilla.org instead (and probably use http?).
my_mothod: This was noticed in bug 464695 comment 1.  The links on the gonefishing error page point to ftp://ftp.mozilla.org, which intentionally blocks access to the latest releases to avoid people linking there directly. They should link to releases.mozilla.org instead (and probably use http?). gonefishing.php links to ftp.mozilla.org, should use releases.mozilla.org instead trivial Bouncer Webtools

description: Created attachment 348516 dead assignment in devutil.c::nssSlotArray_Clone()  Dead assignment, it is obviously taken care of by the gcc's optimisation (verifiable by looking at the md5 of devunit.o before and after the patch), but we care about code quality, right? :)  Found with LLVM/Clang Static Analyser.
my_mothod: Created attachment 348516 dead assignment in devutil.c::nssSlotArray_Clone()  Dead assignment, it is obviously taken care of by the gcc's optimisation (verifiable by looking at the md5 of devunit.o before and after the patch), but we care about code quality, right? :)  Found with LLVM/Clang Static Analyser. dead assignment in devutil.c::nssSlotArray_Clone() trivial Libraries NSS

description: 1. there's nothing about 'Name and Password' that implies anything relating to mail delivery  this could be fixed by using the word 'Identity' instead of 'Name'  2. please add a link near 'PGP/GPG Key Mails sent for security bugs will have no content unless you enter your ASCII-armored public PGP/GPG key here:' which points to the policy announcement/plans.  especially since today this isn't actually true.
my_mothod: 1. there's nothing about 'Name and Password' that implies anything relating to mail delivery  this could be fixed by using the word 'Identity' instead of 'Name'  2. please add a link near 'PGP/GPG Key Mails sent for security bugs will have no content unless you enter your ASCII-armored public PGP/GPG key here:' which points to the policy announcement/plans.  especially since today this isn't actually true. Name and Password tab is odd - hint that it relates to PGP trivial General bugzilla.mozilla.org

description: Created attachment 349620 document messageGenerator.js  Gloda's messageGenerator.js test helper dude lacked comprehensive doxygen.  I had forgotten the secret arguments of one of the functions, so I figured I might as well do the right thing.  Standard8 had originally requested documentation for this file in bug 452221 comment 15.  That request still implies providing big picture documentation at: https://wiki.mozilla.org/MailNews:Home_Page#Automatic_Testing  Also, messageGenerator should move out of gloda's fiefdom into a higher-level mailnews directory.  None of this is important for beta 1; the review can wait until then and then I can get to the other pieces of the puzzle.

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.1b3) Gecko/20090305 Firefox/3.1b3 Build Identifier: xulrunner 1.9.0.7 OSX/darwin X11  When building xulrunner-1.9.0.7 for darwin X11, libxpcom fails to link:  gmake[3]: Entering directory `/opt/local/var/macports/build/_Users_jeremy_src_macports-trunk_dports_devel_xulrunner/work/mozilla/xpcom/stub' rm -f libxpcom.dylib /usr/bin/g++-4.0 -I/opt/local/include  -I/opt/local/include -fno-rtti -fno-exceptions -Wall -Wconversion -Wpointer-arith -Woverloaded-virtual -Wsynth -Wno-ctor-dtor-privacy -Wno-non-virtual-dtor -Wcast-align -Wno-long-long -O2 -fno-strict-aliasing -fpascal-strings -fno-common -fshort-wchar -pthread -pipe  -DNDEBUG -DTRIMMED -O2 -fPIC  -o libxpcom.dylib  nsXPComStub.o     -L/opt/local/lib -framework Cocoa  -Wl,-executable_path,../../dist/bin -Wl,-dead_strip -L../../dist/bin -L../../dist/lib ../../dist/bin/XUL  -L/opt/local/lib -lplds4 -lplc4 -lnspr4 -L/opt/local/lib -dynamiclib -install_name @executable_path/libxpcom.dylib -compatibility_version 1 -current_version 1 -single_module     i686-apple-darwin9-g++-4.0.1: ../../dist/bin/XUL: No such file or directory gmake[3]: *** [libxpcom.dylib] Error 1 gmake[3]: Leaving directory `/opt/local/var/macports/build/_Users_jeremy_src_macports-trunk_dports_devel_xulrunner/work/mozilla/xpcom/stub'   Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: Build xulrunner 1.9.0.7 for darwin X11    It looks like an assumption is being made that Darwin == OSX.  Here's a section from the Makefile.in:  ifeq (Darwin,$(OS_ARCH)) EXTRA_DSO_LDOPTS += $(DIST)/bin/XUL DEPENDENT_LIBS_LIST += XUL else EXTRA_DSO_LIBS = xul DEPENDENT_LIBS_LIST += $(LIB_PREFIX)xul$(DLL_SUFFIX) endif  This should be changed to look for mac or cocoa as the toolkit.  browser/app/Makefile.in does this: ifneq (,$(filter mac cocoa,$(MOZ_WIDGET_TOOLKIT))) LIBS += $(DIST)/bin/XUL else EXTRA_DSO_LIBS += xul endif endif
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.1b3) Gecko/20090305 Firefox/3.1b3 Build Identifier: xulrunner 1.9.0.7 OSX/darwin X11  When building xulrunner-1.9.0.7 for darwin X11, libxpcom fails to link:  gmake[3]: Entering directory `/opt/local/var/macports/build/_Users_jeremy_src_macports-trunk_dports_devel_xulrunner/work/mozilla/xpcom/stub' rm -f libxpcom.dylib /usr/bin/g++-4.0 -I/opt/local/include  -I/opt/local/include -fno-rtti -fno-exceptions -Wall -Wconversion -Wpointer-arith -Woverloaded-virtual -Wsynth -Wno-ctor-dtor-privacy -Wno-non-virtual-dtor -Wcast-align -Wno-long-long -O2 -fno-strict-aliasing -fpascal-strings -fno-common -fshort-wchar -pthread -pipe  -DNDEBUG -DTRIMMED -O2 -fPIC  -o libxpcom.dylib  nsXPComStub.o     -L/opt/local/lib -framework Cocoa  -Wl,-executable_path,../../dist/bin -Wl,-dead_strip -L../../dist/bin -L../../dist/lib ../../dist/bin/XUL  -L/opt/local/lib -lplds4 -lplc4 -lnspr4 -L/opt/local/lib -dynamiclib -install_name @executable_path/libxpcom.dylib -compatibility_version 1 -current_version 1 -single_module     i686-apple-darwin9-g++-4.0.1: ../../dist/bin/XUL: No such file or directory gmake[3]: *** [libxpcom.dylib] Error 1 gmake[3]: Leaving directory `/opt/local/var/macports/build/_Users_jeremy_src_macports-trunk_dports_devel_xulrunner/work/mozilla/xpcom/stub'   Reproducible: Always  Steps to Reproduce: Build xulrunner 1.9.0.7 for darwin X11    It looks like an assumption is being made that Darwin == OSX.  Here's a section from the Makefile.in:  ifeq (Darwin,$(OS_ARCH)) EXTRA_DSO_LDOPTS += $(DIST)/bin/XUL DEPENDENT_LIBS_LIST += XUL else EXTRA_DSO_LIBS = xul DEPENDENT_LIBS_LIST += $(LIB_PREFIX)xul$(DLL_SUFFIX) endif  This should be changed to look for mac or cocoa as the toolkit.  browser/app/Makefile.in does this: ifneq (,$(filter mac cocoa,$(MOZ_WIDGET_TOOLKIT))) LIBS += $(DIST)/bin/XUL else EXTRA_DSO_LIBS += xul endif endif xpcom linking failure - dist/bin/XUL trivial General Firefox Build System

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre; .NET CLR 3.5; ffco7) Gecko/20090517 Minefield/3.6a1pre Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre; .NET CLR 3.5; ffco7) Gecko/20090517 Minefield/3.6a1pre  After configuring Firefox to use a proxy, I navigated to a page in one browser window, and simultaneously opened another browser window and navigated to another page. Each window popped up a proxy username/password dialog. I entered my username and password in one window, and the dialog went away, my page loaded, and on the notification bar that appeared I indicated to remember that password. Next, I switched to the other window, entered my username and password, the dialog went away, my page loaded, and on the notification bar that appeared I indicated to remember that same password. Rather than going away, that notification bar did nothing. The Error Console had this to say:  Error: uncaught exception: [Exception... "'This login already exists.' when calling method: [nsILoginManager::addLogin]"  nsresult: "0x8057001e (NS_ERROR_XPC_JS_THREW_STRING)"  location: "JS frame :: file:///C:/Program%20Files/Mozilla%20Firefox%20Minefield/components/nsLoginManagerPrompter.js :: anonymous :: line 687"  data: no]  Reproducible: Didn't try
my_mothod: User-Agent:       Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre; .NET CLR 3.5; ffco7) Gecko/20090517 Minefield/3.6a1pre Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2a1pre; .NET CLR 3.5; ffco7) Gecko/20090517 Minefield/3.6a1pre  After configuring Firefox to use a proxy, I navigated to a page in one browser window, and simultaneously opened another browser window and navigated to another page. Each window popped up a proxy username/password dialog. I entered my username and password in one window, and the dialog went away, my page loaded, and on the notification bar that appeared I indicated to remember that password. Next, I switched to the other window, entered my username and password, the dialog went away, my page loaded, and on the notification bar that appeared I indicated to remember that same password. Rather than going away, that notification bar did nothing. The Error Console had this to say:  Error: uncaught exception: [Exception... "'This login already exists.' when calling method: [nsILoginManager::addLogin]"  nsresult: "0x8057001e (NS_ERROR_XPC_JS_THREW_STRING)"  location: "JS frame :: file:///C:/Program%20Files/Mozilla%20Firefox%20Minefield/components/nsLoginManagerPrompter.js :: anonymous :: line 687"  data: no]  Reproducible: Didn't try notification bar remains after clicking "remember login" trivial Password Manager Toolkit

description: Created attachment 384021 duplicate kwargs  There are two classes which call methods using duplicate keyword arguments in buildbotcustom/process.factory.py.  This becomes an issue on Python 2.6.  I understand that we don't use 2.6 right now, but it seems like it would be good to clean up.
my_mothod: Created attachment 384021 duplicate kwargs  There are two classes which call methods using duplicate keyword arguments in buildbotcustom/process.factory.py.  This becomes an issue on Python 2.6.  I understand that we don't use 2.6 right now, but it seems like it would be good to clean up. Duplicate Keyword Arguments in factory.py trivial General Release Engineering

description: Created attachment 402960 v1  In bug/create/create.html.tmpl, user-message.html.tmpl is loaded with INCLUDE instead of PROCESS. I ran into a situation where I wanted to use it kind of like a "hook" in an extension for a client, but I couldn't modify external variables because it was called with INCLUDE instead of PROCESS for no particular reason.  I've attached a one-liner patch to change it.

I've attached a one-liner patch to change it. PROCESS user-message instead of INCLUDE'ing it trivial User Interface Bugzilla

description: Created attachment 404810 Fix  Obviously, when load uses the filename argument to read the status, unload to should use it to save the status :)
my_mothod: Created attachment 404810 Fix  Obviously, when load uses the filename argument to read the status, unload to should use it to save the status :) gFolderTree.unload takes filename to save status to, but does not use it! trivial Folder and Message Lists Thunderbird

description: Created attachment 405792 fix: s/printf(foo)/printf("%s", foo)/  When building mozilla-central, I get 6 warnings of this type in NSS code:  > secutil.c:1066: warning: format not a string literal and no format arguments  This is GCC detecting a potential format string attack ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Format_string_attack ).  This is mostly an issue when the printed string is user-controlled, but it's trivial to fix, so I don't see why we shouldn't just fix it.  The attached patch fixes 6 instances of this problem in NSS.  (Combined with the patch on bug 521677, this fixes all warnings of this type that I hit when building current mozilla-central.)
my_mothod: Created attachment 405792 fix: s/printf(foo)/printf("%s", foo)/  When building mozilla-central, I get 6 warnings of this type in NSS code:  > secutil.c:1066: warning: format not a string literal and no format arguments  This is GCC detecting a potential format string attack ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Format_string_attack ).  This is mostly an issue when the printed string is user-controlled, but it's trivial to fix, so I don't see why we shouldn't just fix it.  The attached patch fixes 6 instances of this problem in NSS.  (Combined with the patch on bug 521677, this fixes all warnings of this type that I hit when building current mozilla-central.) Fix NSS build warnings: "format not a string literal and no format arguments" trivial Tools NSS

description: Currently, the named character name table in the HTML5 parser uses byte[] in Java and static byte array-backed heap-allocated jArray objects in C++.  It would be desirable to use java.lang.String objects in Java (to avoid the added footprint of the byte arrays in Java and GWT-compiled JS) and to use a dedicated struct type that could respond to charAt() and length() in C++ (to avoid the heap-allocated jArray objects).
my_mothod: Currently, the named character name table in the HTML5 parser uses byte[] in Java and static byte array-backed heap-allocated jArray objects in C++.  It would be desirable to use java.lang.String objects in Java (to avoid the added footprint of the byte arrays in Java and GWT-compiled JS) and to use a dedicated struct type that could respond to charAt() and length() in C++ (to avoid the heap-allocated jArray objects). [HTML5] Named character names should use Java String and a dedicated type in C++ trivial DOM: HTML Parser Core

description: nsHtml5NamedCharacters has a member called HILO_ACCEL. This poses two problems:  1) It's ugly in C++.  2) Having HILO_ACCEL and the named character tables in the same class makes the Java source fail to compile with java.  Therefore, HILO_ACCEL should be split into a separate class.
my_mothod: nsHtml5NamedCharacters has a member called HILO_ACCEL. This poses two problems:  1) It's ugly in C++.  2) Having HILO_ACCEL and the named character tables in the same class makes the Java source fail to compile with java.  Therefore, HILO_ACCEL should be split into a separate class. [HTML5] Split HILO_ACCEL into a separate class trivial DOM: HTML Parser Core

description: It is unnecessary to have two growable buffers in the HTML5 tokenizer. There should be only one growable buffer and a fixed-size buffer for dealing with the case of avoiding losing the data following an unterminated named character reference that is also a prefix of another named character reference when tokenizing an attribute value. (e.g. foo="&notiX")
my_mothod: It is unnecessary to have two growable buffers in the HTML5 tokenizer. There should be only one growable buffer and a fixed-size buffer for dealing with the case of avoiding losing the data following an unterminated named character reference that is also a prefix of another named character reference when tokenizing an attribute value. (e.g. foo="&notiX") [HTML5] Consolidate strBuf and longStrBuf use in the tokenizer trivial DOM: HTML Parser Core

description: Shouldn't forums.views.reply be decorated @require_POST? I don't think we ever throw GETs at it, and similar views like lock_thread() are @require_POST.  Note that it isn't hurting anything at present; it falls back to returning a list of posts, with a form error, on GET.
my_mothod: Shouldn't forums.views.reply be decorated @require_POST? I don't think we ever throw GETs at it, and similar views like lock_thread() are @require_POST.  Note that it isn't hurting anything at present; it falls back to returning a list of posts, with a form error, on GET. forums.views.reply() should require POST method trivial Forum support.mozilla.org

description: At the moment (or at least once I merge the 569286-question-editing branch), things like "Asked by jsocol Today at 4:33 PM" appear at places like https://support-stage.mozilla.com/en-US/questions/19.  * "Today" should be lowercase so this looks like the sentence it almost is. * There should be no space before "PM", because it causes ugly wrappings in the small space we're jamming it into, like this:      Today at 4:44     PM  * Possibly, "PM" should be lowercase to match the mockup at https://bug556285.bugzilla.mozilla.org/attachment.cgi?id=441873, but that may be more of a personal preference.

description: User-Agent:       Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 6.1; Trident/4.0; SLCC2; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; .NET CLR 3.0.30618; .NET CLR 3.5.30618; InfoPath.2; Tablet PC 2.0; Zune 3.0; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E) Build Identifier: 3.6.10  Phishing protection should back off during OS Resume to avoid interfering with the responsiveness of logon.  The Phishing feature periodically updates the database and writes out the sqlite file.  On laptop machines the writes can occur during resume thus impacting logon time.  It is more of a problem for users with laptops due to slower disks.  As an example, today during resume on my Win7 Toshiba laptop, Firefox read about 23 MB and wrote about 60 MB to C:\Users\*\AppData\Local\Mozilla\FireFox\Profiles\igrvz36w.default\urlclassifier3.sqlite and about 1 MB to *.sqlite-journal.  The elapsed time for the writes was 62 seconds.    The problem is compounded for multiple user sessions.  (Win7 starter edition does not allow multiple accounts so that may not be an issue for some users.  The author of this bug shares machines with other family members each having a separate account.)  I would guess the cause is cache invalidation due to timeout.  This would cause a "thundering herd" problem of waking up to do work at an inconvenient time.  Reproducible: Didn't try  Steps to Reproduce: 1. On a Win7 laptop, log on and start Firefox 2. Close the case. 3. Wait 45 minutes (or time sufficient to invalidate the phishing cache). 4. Open the case.  You could use Windows Performance Analyer (xperf) to trace the physical disk IO: xperf -on base pause rem ... close the case, wait an hour, open case and log in xperf -d mytrace.etl  Actual Results:   During resume I measured 23 MB physical reads and 60 MB physical writes over 62 elapsed seconds during resume (entering password).  UI was barely responsive during this time.  Expected Results:   Responsive login experience.  For background on the Phishing Protection feature see https://wiki.mozilla.org/Phishing_Protection:_Design_Documentation#Client_Backoff  See also related bugs: Bug 518234 - Allow urlclassifier lookup into only one table Bug 329714 - check for performance impact (phishing protection) Bug 466173 - RFE: per-profile firefox anti-phishing urlclassifier3.sqlite is wasteful, want system-wide copy

The Phishing feature periodically updates the database and writes out the sqlite file.  On laptop machines the writes can occur during resume thus impacting logon time.  It is more of a problem for users with laptops due to slower disks. The elapsed time for the writes was 62 seconds.    The problem is compounded for multiple user sessions. Reproducible: Didn't try  Steps to Reproduce: 1. On a Win7 laptop, log on and start Firefox 2. Close the case. 3. Wait 45 minutes (or time sufficient to invalidate the phishing cache). 4. Open the case.  You could use Windows Performance Analyer (xperf) to trace the physical disk IO: xperf -on base pause rem ... close the case, wait an hour, open case and log in xperf -d mytrace.etl  Actual Results:   During resume I measured 23 MB physical reads and 60 MB physical writes over 62 elapsed seconds during resume (entering password).  UI was barely responsive during this time.  Expected Results:   Responsive login experience.  For background on the Phishing Protection feature see https://wiki.mozilla.org/Phishing_Protection:_Design_Documentation#Client_Backoff  See also related bugs: Bug 518234 - Allow urlclassifier lookup into only one table Bug 329714 - check for performance impact (phishing protection) Bug 466173 - RFE: per-profile firefox anti-phishing urlclassifier3.sqlite is wasteful, want system-wide copy Phishing protection should back off during OS Resume trivial Safe Browsing Toolkit

description: This is a weird one... so when I press enter/return in the modal window that pops up after I submit a new document, the background is dimmed.  We should, instead, submit the modal window.  Filing as trivial since it's probably an easy fix, and not urgent at all.
my_mothod: This is a weird one... so when I press enter/return in the modal window that pops up after I submit a new document, the background is dimmed.  We should, instead, submit the modal window.  Filing as trivial since it's probably an easy fix, and not urgent at all. Pressing return/enter key in the modal window when posting a new document dims the background trivial General support.mozilla.org

description: Examples:  http://mxr.mozilla.org/build/source/buildbot-configs/mozilla2/win32/mozilla-central/debug/mozconfig http://mxr.mozilla.org/build/source/buildbot-configs/seamonkey/win32/comm-central-trunk/debug/mozconfig { ac_add_options --enable-jemalloc ... ac_add_options --enable-trace-malloc }  http://mxr.mozilla.org/build/source/buildbot-configs/thunderbird/win32/comm-central/debug/mozconfig { # Jemalloc gets disabled if trace-malloc is on, so don't bother enabling it here #ac_add_options --enable-jemalloc  ac_add_options --enable-trace-malloc }  Indeed: http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/configure.in { 7227 if test "$NS_TRACE_MALLOC"; then 7228     MOZ_MEMORY= 7229 fi }  This is not breaking anything, but it is rather useless and misleading!  ***  In addition, we should had an AC_MSG_WARN() in this case, to let the user know.
my_mothod: Examples:  http://mxr.mozilla.org/build/source/buildbot-configs/mozilla2/win32/mozilla-central/debug/mozconfig http://mxr.mozilla.org/build/source/buildbot-configs/seamonkey/win32/comm-central-trunk/debug/mozconfig { ac_add_options --enable-jemalloc ... ac_add_options --enable-trace-malloc }  http://mxr.mozilla.org/build/source/buildbot-configs/thunderbird/win32/comm-central/debug/mozconfig { # Jemalloc gets disabled if trace-malloc is on, so don't bother enabling it here #ac_add_options --enable-jemalloc  ac_add_options --enable-trace-malloc }  Indeed: http://mxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/source/configure.in { 7227 if test "$NS_TRACE_MALLOC"; then 7228     MOZ_MEMORY= 7229 fi }  This is not breaking anything, but it is rather useless and misleading!  ***  In addition, we should had an AC_MSG_WARN() in this case, to let the user know. Debug Windows .mozconfig with '--enable-trace-malloc' uselessly have overridden '--enable-jemalloc' trivial General Release Engineering

description: Two things:  1. Add locale to the links. 2. Add a class to the <a> tag.  1. Right now new document links are: /kb/new?title=New page Instead, if viewing this in a, e.g., French article, they should be: /fr/kb/new?title=New page  2. This should help us style the links accordingly
my_mothod: Two things:  1. Add locale to the links. 2. Add a class to the <a> tag.  1. Right now new document links are: /kb/new?title=New page Instead, if viewing this in a, e.g., French article, they should be: /fr/kb/new?title=New page  2. This should help us style the links accordingly Improved links to new documents trivial Knowledge Base Software support.mozilla.org
